snippet: A top government economist has concluded that high-speed trading firms are taking significant profits from traditional investors.
abstract: Commodity Futures Trading Commission chief economist Andrei Kirilenko concludes that high-speed trading firms are taking significant profits from traditional investors; states traders make average profit of as much as $5.05 each time they go up against small traders buying and selling widely used financial contracts.

byline.original: By NATHANIEL POPPER and CHRISTOPHER LEONARD

lead_paragraph: A top government economist has concluded that high-speed trading firms are taking significant profits from traditional investors.

headline.main: High-Speed Traders Profit at Expense of Ordinary Investors, a Study Says
headline.print_headline: High-Speed Trades Hurt Investors, a Study Says
